{{Infobox civil conflict |title=Impact of the Arab Spring |image=[[File:Voa beijing 230 20feb11.jpg|300px]] |caption=The large silent crowd gathered in front of a [[McDonald's]] restaurant near [[Tiananmen Square]] in [[Beijing]] |place= Worldwide outside the Middle East |coordinates= |date= Early 2011 - present |methods= |goal= |causes= |status=Ongoing |result= <!-- fill when conflict is over, status should be empty --> |fatalities= |injuries=<!-- we don't know the number --> |arrests=<!-- we don't know the number, some arrested then escaped --> }} The '''impact of the Arab Spring''' concerns protests or attempts to organise growing protest movements that were inspired by or similar to the [[Arab Spring]] in the [[Arab world|Arab-majority]] states of North Africa and the Middle East, according to commentators, organisers, and critics. These demonstrations and protest efforts have all been critical of the government in their respective countries, though they have ranged from calls for the incumbent government to make certain policy changes to attempts to bring down the current political system in its entirety. In some countries, protests have become large or widespread enough to effect change at the national level, as in [[2011 Armenian protests|Armenia]], while in others, such as [[2011 Djiboutian protests|Djibouti]], were swiftly suppressed.
Protests considered to be inspired by the Arab Spring have taken place on every inhabited continent, with varying degrees of success and prominence. On October 15, 2011, the subsidiary [[Occupy Wall Street|"Occupy"]] and [[2011 Spanish protests|Indignants]] movements inspired [[15 October 2011 global protests|protests in 951 cities in 82 countries]].
==Background== A number of popular protests by citizens against their governments occurred in nations around the world, both following and concurrently with the Arab Spring, and many of these were reported to have been inspired by events in the Arab World starting at the end of 2010, creating a network of diffusion.<ref name="Hofheinz">Hofheinz, Albrecht, [http://www.fes.de/ipg/IPG3_2005/07HOFHEINZ.PDF The Internet in the Arab World: Playground for Political Liberalization], International Politics and Society, 2005-03-00.</ref><ref name="Zhukov">Zhukov, Yuri and Stewart, Brandon, [http://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/5142122/neighbors_isq_preprint.pdf?sequence=1 Choosing your neighbors: Networks of diffusion in international relations], Forthcoming, International Studies Quarterly (Harvard), p. 1-, 19 et seq..</ref>
Some potentially vulnerable states that have not yet seen such protests have taken a variety of preemptive measures to avoid such displays occurring in their own countries; some of these states and others have experienced political fallout as a result of their own governmental actions and reactions to events which their own citizens are seeing reported from abroad.<ref name="Hofheinz" /><ref name="Hroub">Hroub, Khaled, [http://www.abc.net.au/religion/articles/2011/10/20/3344402.htm Al Jazeera: the source of Arab springs], Australian Broadcasting Corporation, 2011-10-20.</ref><ref name="barnett">Barnett, Clive, [http://oro.open.ac.uk/29008/2/Theory_and_events.pdf Theory and events], Geoforum, 42(3), pp. 263â265, 2011.</ref><ref name="Dunn">Dunn, Alexandra, The Arab Spring: Revolution and Shifting Geopolitics: Unplugging a Nation: State Media Strategy During Egypt's January 25 Uprising, 35 Fletcher F. World Aff. 15, Summer, 2011.</ref>
==Protests== ===Sub-Saharan Africa=== ====Angola==== A local radio station in Angola said the police arrested about 20 demonstrators who gathered in the country's capital to protest against Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos, who has been in power for 32 years. Radio Ecclesia reported Monday that a small number of demonstrators gathered at midnight in response to internet calls for an anti-government demonstration. Media reports say police also arrested three local journalists covering the demonstration, but released them later Monday. President dos Santos' party rallied more than 20,000 pro-government protesters Saturday to march in Luanda in response to rumors of Monday's demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/feedarticle/9533081 | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=World news | date=23 January 2008}}</ref>
====Burkina Faso==== {{main|2011 BurkinabÃ¨ protests}}
Longtime President [[Blaise CompaorÃ©]] faced the strongest protests against his regime starting in February 2011, with tens of thousands protesting on 14 April 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110415-shots-fired-inside-burkina-faso-presidential-compound |title=Shots fired inside Burkina Faso presidential compound |publisher=FRANCE 24 |date=2011-04-15 |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> Soldiers soon joined the protests, prompting CompaorÃ© to dissolve his cabinet, appoint a new prime minister, replace his army chief, and name himself defense minister.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13116774|agency=BBC News|date=18 April 2011|accessdate=24 April 2011|title=Burkina Faso army mutiny spreads to fourth city}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/22/burkina.faso.government/|agency=CNN International|date=23 April 2011|accessdate=24 April 2011|title=Ministers fired, smaller government created in Africa's Burkina Faso|first=Ouezen Louis|last=Oulon}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.southafricafocus.com/2011/04/22/burkina-faso-president-blaise-compaore-takes-charge-of-defense-rtt-news/|agency=RTT News|date=22 April 2011|accessdate=24 April 2011|title=Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore Takes Charge Of Defense}}</ref> Students joined protests in [[Ouagadougou]] on 19 April as well, [[BBC News]] reported.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/africa/students-join-burkina-faso-protests-1.1058743|agency=IOL News|date=19 April 2011|accessdate=24 April 2011|title=Students join Burkina Faso protests}}</ref> On 22 April, a coalition of 34 BurkinabÃ© opposition parties called for a rally on 30 April to demand CompaorÃ©'s resignation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=182823|agency=The Daily Star|date=23 April 2011|accessdate=24 April 2011|title=Burkina opposition calls anti-president demo}}</ref>
====Cameroon==== Opposition groups, trade unions and Diaspora groups had prepared "Egypt-like" protests in [[Cameroon]] to call for President [[Paul Biya]] to step down. However, the protest movement was poorly organised and coordinated,<ref name="afrol_cam_egyptlike">{{cite web|url=http://www.afrol.com/articles/37405|title=Cameroon plans "Egypt-like" protests|date=22 February 2011|publisher=afrol News|accessdate=26 February 2011}}</ref> and protesters in [[Douala]] and [[YaoundÃ©]] were outnumbered by police, resulting in protesters being dispersed by the police before being able to organise a large crowd.<ref name="afrol_cam_crushed">{{cite web|url=http://www.afrol.com/articles/37416|title=Police easily cracks down Cameroon protests|date=23 February 2011|publisher=afrol News|accessdate=26 February 2011}}</ref>
====Djibouti==== {{main|2011 Djiboutian protests}} On 3 February, demonstrations began when about three hundred people protested peacefully against President [[Ismail Omar Guelleh]] in [[Djibouti (city)|Djibouti City]], urging him to not run for another term; the protesters further asked for more liberty as well as for political and social reform.<ref>{{Cite news|title=People in Djibouti protest against President Gelleh|author=|newspaper=Somalilandpress|year=|url=http://somalilandpress.com/people-in-djibouti-protest-againts-president-gelleh-19925|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Protests soon increased, however, as thousands rallied against the president, many vowing to remain at the site until their demands were met. On 18 February, an estimated 30,000 Dijiboutians protested in central Djibouti City against the president, maintaining that the constitutional change of the previous year, which allowed him a third term, was illegal. The demonstration escalated into clashes with the police, and at least two persons were killed and many injured when police used live ammunition and teargas against the protesters.<ref name="Afrol.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.afrol.com/articles/37449 |title=Mass arrests stopped further Djibouti protests |publisher=Afrol.com |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref> On 19 and 24 February, protest leaders were arrested and after they failed to turn up on the 24th, opposition leader Bourhan Mohammed Ali stated he feared the protests had lost momentum.<ref name="Afrol.com"/> The last protest was planned for 11 March, but security forces stopped the protest and detained 4 opposition leaders. No protests or planned protests have occurred since.
====Ivory Coast==== In [[CÃ´te d'Ivoire]] (Ivory Coast), peace activist [[Aya Virginie Toure]] organized thousands of women<ref>{{cite news | title = Women in Ivory Coast lead the revolution against Gbagbo | url = http://newscastmedia.com/blog/2011/03/09/women-in-ivory-coast-lead-the-revolution-against-gbagbo/ | date = March 9, 2011 | work = Newscast Media | format = article | accessdate = 2011-03-09}}</ref> in numerous peaceful protests across the country.<ref>{{cite news | title = The Ivory Coast Effect | url = http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2011/03/the-ivory-coast-effect.html | date = March 22, 2011 | work = The New Yorker | format = article | accessdate = 2011-03-22}}</ref> They were met by security forces with tanks that opened fire.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12637088 |title=BBC News - Ivory Coast: Women 'shot during pro-Ouattara march' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> In an impassioned interview on [[BBC News]], Toure compared the [[Second Ivorian Civil War]]<ref>{{cite news | title = Ivory Coast's well-armed rebels making quick work of revolution | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/apr/01/ivory-coast-new-forces-rebels-revolution | date = April 1, 2011 | work = The Guardian | format = article | accessdate = 2011-04-01 | location=London | first=David | last=Smith}}</ref> to the [[2011 Libyan civil war]] and asked for support from the [[international community]]. She called for military intervention to remove [[Laurent Gbagbo]] from power.<ref>{{cite news | title = A plea for help from an Ivorian women's leader amid the violent power struggle | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/p00ff0jq/Outlook_23_03_2011/ | date = March 23, 2011 | work = BBC Radio | format = radio broadcast | accessdate = 2011-03-23}}</ref>
Nigerian Foreign Minister [[Henry Odein Ajumogobia]] accused the [[international community]] of "contradictions" by imposing a no-fly zone over Libya and focusing on the civil war in Libya, but failing to take action to protect civilians in the Ivory Coast.<ref>{{cite news | title = Nigeria: Ignoring Ivory Coast is hypocritical | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20045674-503543.html | date = March 21, 2011 | work = CBS News/World | format = article | accessdate = 2011-03-21 | first=Joshua | last=Norman}}</ref> Oil production in Libya is seen as a more strategic commodity than cocoa in the Ivory Coast, <ref>{{cite news | title = The Root: Libya Eclipses Ivory Coast In The Media | url = http://www.npr.org/2011/03/14/134528904/the-root-libya-eclipses-ivory-coast-in-the-media | date = March 14, 2011 | work = NPR | format = news report | accessdate = 2011-03-14}}</ref> which influenced the international response to the turmoil facing both countries.<ref>{{cite news | title = Oil vs. cocoa: Why Ivory Coast isn't like Libya | url = http://articles.cnn.com/2011-04-04/world/ivory.coast.libya_1_ivory-coast-laurent-gbagbo-libya?_s=PM:WORLD | date = April 4, 2011 | work = CNN World | format = article | accessdate = 2011-04-04}}</ref>
====Gabon==== On 29 January, riot police in [[Gabon]] fired tear gas to break up a protest by around 5,000 opposition supporters, where according to witnesses, up to 20 people were wounded. It was the second such protest since opposition leader [[Andre Mba Obame]] declared himself president on January 25 and urged people to take inspiration from Tunisia's uprising.<ref>{{cite news|title=Police use tear gas to break up Gabon protest |url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE70T00R20110130 |agency=Reuters Africa |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> Obame subsequently hid out in the local [[United Nations Development Programme]] office, while President Bongo shut down TV stations and allegedly kidnapped members of the opposition. The UN is accusing Gabon's police of invading and beating students within the university. Although initial protests overwhelmingly consisted of opposition loyalists, the unrest appears to be developing into a wider social conflict, with students leading the protests.<ref name="csmonitor1">{{cite news|title=Now that Egypt's Mubarak is out, could Gabon's Bongo be next? |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Africa/Africa-Monitor/2011/0212/Now-that-Egypt-s-Mubarak-is-out-could-Gabon-s-Bongo-be-next |agency=CS Monitor |accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref>
====Malawi==== {{main|2011 Malawi protests}} On 21 July protesters in [[Mzuzu]], [[Blantyre]] and [[Lilongwe]] took out a march against President [[Bingu wa Mutharika]] because of anger of corruption and a fuel shortage. The ensuing tear gas firing by security forces was then followed up with riots that led to the deaths of 10 people.
====Mozambique==== An elite police unit crushed a workers' protest on 6 April, detaining a number of demonstrators and leaving several injured. At least one protester died as a result of the crackdown. The Mozambican Human Rights League called for an investigation and demanded the commander of the unit step down. [[Al Jazeera]] connected the incident to a broader wave of unrest sparked by the events in North Africa.<ref>{{cite news|title=A continent's discontent|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/04/201141014942125983.html|agency=Al Jazeera English|date=12 April 2011|accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref>
====Swaziland==== Thousands of people protested in [[Swaziland]] against the absolute monarch [[Mswati III]], who is known for his lavish spending; the government's reaction was a swift crackdown, with tear gas and water cannons used.<ref>{{cite news|author=April 13, 2011 1:16AM |url=http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/swazi-police-use-tear-gas-on-protest/story-e6frfku0-1226038184313 |title=Swazi police use tear gas on protest |publisher=News.com.au |date=2011-04-13 |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref>
====Uganda==== [[Ugandan]] President [[Yoweri Museveni]] was [[Ugandan general election, 2011|declared the winner of Uganda's 2011 general election]] on 11 February amidst opposition denunciations. [[Kizza Besigye]], the chairman of the opposition coalition finished second with 26.01% of the vote. Besigye warned that Uganda was ripe for an Egypt-style revolt after Museveni's more than two decades in power.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/uganda/8336879/Ugandan-president-comfortably-wins-re-election.html|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph|title=Ugandan president comfortably wins re-election|date=2011-02-20}}</ref> The protesters failed to amass in large numbers because, as the ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' suggested, a failure to tally its own results through its own [[SMS]] system was disrupted by the government, who also arrested hundreds of opposition [[field agent]]s. They also suggested that Besigye did not believe his own claim of sparking a revolution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Africa/Africa-Monitor/2011/0222/Why-Uganda-s-Besigye-failed-to-deliver-Egypt-style-protests-after-election-defeat|title=Why Uganda's Besigye failed to deliver Egypt-style protests after election defeat|publisher=CSMonitor.com|year=|accessdate=2011-02-24}}</ref> With unrest growing at the rising prices of food and fuel, the arrest of Kizza Besigye on 28 April was the catalyst for protests and riots across the Ugandan capital, [[Kampala]], in which two were killed.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=David|accessdate=2011-04-29|date=2011-04-29|title=Uganda riots reach capital as anger against President Museveni grows|work=[[The Guardian]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/apr/29/uganda-riots-kampala-museveni|location=London}}</ref>
====Zimbabwe==== Munyaradzi Gwisai, a former opposition member of parliament, organised a meeting to discuss the uprisings in North Africa on 21 February. He, along with 45 others, were arrested and allegedly tortured and face a charge of [[treason]] that carries the death penalty. Many Zimbwabwean migrants to South Africa, who number in the hundreds of thousands, are free to talk of the events. However, past violence in elections and many of the youth and educated middle classes having fled the country there were questions about the pool of protesters to carry out such actions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/21/zimbabwe.unrest.arrests/index.html|work=CNN|title=46 arrested for plotting Egyptian-style coup in Zimbabwe|date=2011-02-21}}</ref><ref name="alj_zimb_gwisai">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/asia/2011/03/20113151258342215.html |title=Violence deters Zimbabwe activists - Asia |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref>
A Million Citizen March<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thezimbabwemail.com/zimbabwe/7398.html |title=Million march demanding Robert Mugabe's immediate resignation â The Zimbabwe Mail |publisher=Thezimbabwemail.com |date= |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> called for in Harare on 1 March went unheeded after a heavy police presence since 26 February continued and a curfew was declared on the night of 28 February.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jonah Hull |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/africa/2011/03/01/zimbabwes-million-citizen-march |title=Zimbabwe's Million Citizen March | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref>
===South Caucasus=== ====Armenia==== {{main|2011 Armenian protests}} Regional unrest reached [[Armenia]] in January as merchants protested a ban on street trading in [[Yerevan]], the former [[Soviet socialist republic]]'s capital. Protesters marched in front of municipal offices and called for Mayor [[Karen Karapetyan]] to "come down", demanding that the ban be lifted.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://asbarez.com/92040/desperate-citizens-protest-new-mayors-ban-on-street-trade-in-yerevan/|agency=Asbarez|date=19 January 2011|accessdate=26 February 2011|title=New Mayor Bans Street Trade in Yerevan}}</ref> Seizing on this rising discontent in the capital city,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.a1plus.am/en/politics/2011/03/1/ltp|agency=A1+ TV|date=1 March 2011|accessdate=26 April 2011|title=Speech by Levon Ter-Petrosyan|first=Levon|last=Ter-Petrosyan}}</ref> the [[Armenian National Congress]], led by former President [[Levon Ter-Petrosian]], started organizing larger, more sharply politicized rallies in Yerevan in February. Rallies have drawn tens of thousands and have continued through April. Protesters demand the release of political prisoners, socio-economic reforms, full access to Yerevan's Freedom Square, and that perpetrators of violence against opposition supporters in the wake of the [[Armenian presidential election, 2008|2008 presidential election]] be brought to justice.<ref>{{citation | title = Protests in Armenia | url = http://195.187.133.42/en/publikacje/eastweek/2011-02-23/protests-armenia | publisher = Eastweek | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=3 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{citation | title = Expert: Armenian political elite will face hard times url = http://en.trend.az/news/politics/1838667.html | publisher = Trend.az | date=2 March 2011 | accessdate=3 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/world/breakingnews/opposition-protest-against-armenias-government-draws-12000-people-in-capital-119488289.html|agency=Winnipeg Free Press|date=8 April 2011|accessdate=21 April 2011|title=Opposition protest against Armenia's government draws 12,000 people in capital}}</ref>
The government has made three major concessions: agreeing to revive and step up a hereto stagnant investigation of the 2008 protest deaths, opening Freedom Square to political rallies from 28 April forward,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://armenianow.com/news/politics/29268/yerevan_liberty_square_opposition_rally|agency=ArmeniaNow|date=26 April 2011|accessdate=28 April 2011|title=Change of Attitude: Yerevan municipality gives permission for Liberty Square rally}}</ref> and issuing a general amnesty covering jailed activists the opposition considers to be political prisoners.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/armenia-plans-amnesty-in-gesture-to-opposition|agency=Reuters AlertNet|date=26 May 2011|accessdate=30 May 2011|title=Armenia plans amnesty in gesture to opposition}}</ref> President [[Serzh Sargsyan]] said in late April that he believed in cooperation between the government and the opposition and that his government was willing to make the "first steps" toward a compromise.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/politics/news/68442/|agency=PanArmenian|date=27 April 2011|accessdate=28 April 2011|title=Sargsyan: authorities ready to take first steps towards opposition}}</ref>
====Azerbaijan==== {{main|2011 Azerbaijani protests}} Youth activists and opposition leaders, inspired by events of the Arab Spring, called for demonstrations on 11 and 12 March. The government responded with a crackdown on gatherings and widespread detentions. [[Reuters]] reported that at least 150 activists were arrested in [[Azerbaijan]] during March.<ref name="LATimesAzer">{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/04/azerbaijan-more-than-200-anti-government-protesters-are-arrested.html|agency=The Los Angeles Times|title=AZERBAIJAN: More than 200 anti-government protesters arrested|date=2 April 2011|accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref> Police arrested close to 300 demonstrators in April,<ref name="LATimesAzer"/> detaining at least four journalists covering the incident as well.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=dark-days-for-freedom-in-turkey-and-azerbaijan-2011-04-19|agency=Hurriyet Daily News|date=20 April 2011|accessdate=24 April 2011|first=Eldar|last=Mamedov|title=Dark days for freedom in Turkey and Azerbaijan}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=182109|agency=The Daily Star|date=18 April 2011|accessdate=24 April 2011|title=Police thwart Azerbaijan democracy rally}}</ref> Dozens more protesters, including at least one journalist who was later released, were arrested in May.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=55610|agency=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|date=6 May 2011|accessdate=16 May 2011|title=Baku Police Break Up Protest Against School Hijab Ban}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/activists_detained_in_azerbaijan/24183827.html|agency=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|date=23 May 2011|accessdate=1 June 2011|title=Azerbaijani Activists Jailed Over Protest}}</ref>
====Georgia==== {{Expand section|date=July 2011}} {{main|2011 Georgian protests}}
===Europe=== {{main|Anti-austerity protests}}
As 2011 progressed, a number of protest movements waxed and waned, all claiming a connection with the Arab Spring and the austerity measures taken by the European Union and it's individual constituent states. The most persistent of these were in Greece, Spain and the United Kingdom, the last of which suffered violent riots in the summer. The so-called [[Occupy Wall Street]] movement called for worldwide demonstrations on October 15, and there were protests in every single [[European Union]] capital, not to mention smaller cities.
====Albania==== {{Main|2011 Albanian opposition demonstrations}} Although located in the [[Balkans]] region of Europe, the influence of the Tunisian uprising{{Citation needed|year=February 2011|date=February 2011}} has spread to [[Albania]], by some measures a Muslim-majority country. After a television broadcast showing Deputy Prime Minister [[Ilir Meta]] trying to influence the decision for awarding a contract to build a power station, [[2011 Albanian Demonstrations|protests against]] [[Sali Berisha]]'s government, organised by the country's [[Socialist Party of Albania|socialist party]] and attended by some 20,000 people in [[Tirana]], turned violent and resulted in three deaths. The country's opposition parties vowed to continue the anti-government protests.
[[Edi Rama]], the mayor of Albania's capital, Tirana, and leader of the Socialist party, blamed Berisha for the deaths and said a day of [[mourning]] would be observed. "After we honour the dead in a show of freedom and justice, we assure Berisha that we will confront him with all the historical and civil responsibility we feel for getting rid of this intolerable regime of thieves." Berisha responded by calling for his supporters to organise a mass protest against the violence. "I call on Albanians to gather on [26 January] in Tirana to protest against the violence. It will be a big demonstration against violence. I warn Edi Rama and his followers, and violent groups of their supporters, that they will face the full force of the law if they dare touch the [government] institutions." He had earlier said that "Albania is not in a state of emergency and will not pass into a state of emergency. But scenarios of violence will not be tolerated." He also accused Rama of trying to foment an uprising like that of Tunisia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/01/2011122134433502716.html|title=Albania opposition vows protests|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=2011-01-22|accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>
====Belarus==== {{Main|2011 Belarusian protests}} Following a [[Belarusian presidential election, 2010|presidential election]] on 2010 protesters continued to maintain their stance against the government. On March 25, police attacked hundreds of opposition activists who tried to hold an anti-government rally. Dozens of the demonstrators were beaten in Minsk, and the rights group [[Vyasna]] says at least 50 were detained.<ref>[http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2011/mar/25/eu-belarus-opposition-rally/Protests ]{{dead link|date=May 2011}}</ref> Protests had been going on since it was alleged that President [[Alexander Lukashenko]] had stolen the [[Belarusian presidential election, 2010|presidential election of Dec. 2010]].
====Croatia==== Anti-government street protests in [[Croatia]] started on 22 February 2011, after a call to protest over the Internet, and have continued almost daily.<ref>{{cite news |title=Internetom kruÅ¾i poziv na prosvjed za ruÅ¡enje Vlade: U utorak u 13 sati na Markovom trgu |author= |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/internetom-kruzi-poziv-na-prosvjed-za-rusenje-vlade--u-utorak-na-markovom-trgu/926826/ |newspaper=Jutarnji List |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011|language=Croatian}}</ref> The protests have brought together diverse political persuasions in response to recent government corruption scandals and worries regarding upcoming [[Accession of Croatia to the European Union|EU accession]], and are calling for the resignation of the [[Croatian Prime Minister]] [[Jadranka Kosor]] and [[Croatian parliamentary election, 2011|early elections]]. They have been met by a violent police reaction and a ban on assembly in front of the [[Croatian Parliament]] in [[Zagreb]].<ref> {{cite news |title=Ni ovcama nije lako |author=M. BarukÄiÄ |url=http://www.h-alter.org/vijesti/hrvatska/ni-ovcama-nije-lako |newspaper=H-Alter |date=22 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011|language=Croatian}}</ref><ref> {{cite news |title=Suzavac na zagrebaÄkim ulicama |author=M.K. |url=http://www.h-alter.org/vijesti/hrvatska/suzavac-na-zagrebackim-ulicama |newspaper=H-Alter |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011|language=Croatian}}</ref> On February 26, tens of thousands of protesters met in the Croatian capital [[Zagreb]]'s [[Ban JelaÄiÄ Square]] to express their support for indicted [[Croatian War of Independence]] veterans and ask [[Prime Minister of Croatia|Prime Minister]] [[Jadranka Kosor]]'s [[Government of Croatia|government]] to resign.<ref name="Jutarnji">http://www.jutarnji.hr/braniteljski-prosvjed--vise-stotina-ljudi-sa-slikama-gotovine-i-transparentima-okupiralo-trg/928060/</ref> Several dozen of people were injured and arrested as anti-government protests degenerated into clashes with police.<ref name="Jutarnji"/><ref>http://www.france24.com/en/20110226-clashes-erupt-croatian-anti-government-protests</ref> In the next few weeks the number of protesters rose to some 10 000 people<ref> {{cite news |title=http://www.masa-hr.org/content/1-mali-2-mala-10-000-malih-indijanaca|newspaper=MASA |date=5 March 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011|language=Croatian}}</ref> but later depleted and the protests eventually stopped.
==== Germany ==== On 25 February 2011, several hundred protestors rallied in Berlin urging defense minister [[Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg]] to step down after being stripped of his doctorate because of plagiarism. The protestors waved shoes in reference of the Egypt protests. The evidence of the plagiarism as well as the protests spread on the internet. Guttenberg resigned office on 1 March 2011.<ref>{{cite news | title=Guttbye Guttenberg |url=http://www.economist.com/node/18285902|newspaper=The Economist |accessdate=20 June 2011 |date=3 March 2011}}</ref>
==== United Kingdom ==== [[File:J30 March - Barkers Pool.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Protestors gather in Sheffield to demonstrate against government plans to change public sector pensions.]] {{main|2011 United Kingdom anti-austerity protests|2011 England riots}} Some have factored the English Riots of August 2011 to youth disenfranchisement with the state similar to what has been seen in the Arab Spring.<ref>{{Cite news |title=From the Arab Spring to Liverpool? |last=Ryan |first=Yasmin |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/08/2011811122931660627.html |work=http://english.aljazeera.net |date=11 August 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-20}}</ref>
====Greece==== [[File:2011 Greece Uprising.jpg|thumb|Demonstrators in front of the Greek parliament, 29 May.]] {{main|2010–2011 Greek protests}} The impact of the Arab Spring and the [[2011 Spanish protests]] was a major source of influence for the latest wave of anti-government protests in Greece.<ref name="Euronews Greece">{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/05/25/outraged-greek-youth-follow-spanish-example/ |title=Outraged Greek youth follow Spanish example |date=25 May 2011 |publisher=www.euronews.eu |accessdate=30 May 2011 |quote=First the Arab world, then Madrid, now Athens. Outraged Greek youth has taken its lead from the Arab spring and Spanish protests over unemployment.}}</ref><ref name="BBC Greek Revolution">{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13830466 |title=Greece crisis: Revolution in the offing? |date=19 June 2011 |publisher=www.bbc.co.uk |accessdate=20 June 2011 |quote=Inspired by the Arab uprisings, they have dug in to oppose further spending cuts in exchange for a second bail-out by the EU and IMF.}}</ref> The Greek protests were organized over the internet, and the focal point of the demonstrations is [[Athens]]' [[Syntagma Square|Syntagma]] (or Constitution) Square. The Indignant Citizens Movement has been holding protests in Athens and over 30 other Greek cities since May 25, 2011,<ref name="Euronews Greece" /> with 30,000 attending the first demonstration in Athens on the first day.<ref name="Euronews Greece" /> The most massive demonstration was on June 5, and some estimates put the number of protesters in front of the Greek parliament to over 300,000, while low estimates place the number to well over 100,000.<ref name="Skai 5">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/171405/deutero-kalesma-europaikou-xesikomou/ |title=ÎÎµÏÏÎµÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ¬Î»ÎµÏÎ¼Î± ÎµÏ ÏÏÏÎ±ÏÎºÎ¿Ï Î¾ÎµÏÎ·ÎºÏÎ¼Î¿Ï |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Eleftherotypia 5">{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=281844 |title=ÎÎºÎºÏÏÎ±Î½ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ® Î»Î±Î¿Î¸Î¬Î»Î±ÏÏÎ± ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Proto Thema 5">{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=126165 |title=300.000 ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ ÏÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÎ¿ ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¸Î®Î½Î±Ï! |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref>
The reasons for the demonstrations across Greece were the harsh austerity measures the country was forced to take as part of an [[International Monetary Fund]]–[[European Union]] bailout plan in 2010 that were ineffective, the people's belief that the politicians are corrupt and do not serve the people but international interests, the country's continuously renewed two-party system, high numbers of unemployment, especially for the youth, the government's proposal for new austerity measures, the presence of the [[International Monetary Fund]] in the country, and others.<ref name="Real Democracy Now! demands">{{cite web |url=http://real-democracy.gr/el/%CF%83%CF%84%CF%8C%CF%87%CE%BF%CE%B9-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%BA%CE%B9%CE%BD%CE%AE%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82%CF%83%CF%85%CE%B6%CE%B7%CF%84%CE%AE%CF%83%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82 |title=Î£ÏÏÏÎ¿Î¹ ÏÎ¿Ï ÎºÎ¹Î½Î®Î¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï/Î£Ï Î¶Î·ÏÎ®ÏÎµÎ¹Ï |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.real-democracy.gr |accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref>
The protests continued, and during the week of October 16, over half a million people were on the streets in a general strike that shut down the country and turned violent, causing scores of injuries and at least one death.
==== Northern Cyprus ==== On 28 January, [[Turkish Cypriot]] protesters, some of which carried [[flag of Cyprus|flags of The Republic of Cyprus]] gathered in [[Northern Cyprus|Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus]] to protest the economic reforms and the Turkish government. Turkish Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip ErdoÄan]] accused the protesters of supporting the [[Greece|Greeks]], with whom Turkey has long contested [[Cyprus]]' status.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=erdogan-holds-closed-door-talks-with-former-turkish-cypriot-leader-2011-02-07 |title=Turkish PM holds talks with former northern Cypriot president|publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> The protest has been called Yasemin Devrimi, or the "Yasmin Revolution".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmahaber.com/kktc-ikinci-misir-olur-38934h.html |title=KKTC Ä°kinci MÄ±sÄ±r Olur | Haber Sondakika GÃ¼ncel Haberler |publisher=Elma Haber |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> Mehmet ÃakÄ±cÄ±, the leader of Toplumcu Demokrasi Partisi (TDP), an opposition party in Northern Cyprus, compared the government of Northern Cyprus to [[Egypt]]ian President [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s government. ÃakÄ±cÄ± also asserted that the protest in Cyprus was larger than the [[2011 Egyptian revolution|protest in Egypt]] if the population differences were taken into account,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.samanyoluhaber.com/h_508993_kktcdeki-siyasi-partiler,-gosterilere-turkiyeden-daha-ozenli-bir-yaklasim-istedi.html |title=KKTC'deki siyasi partiler, gÃ¶sterilere TÃ¼rkiye'den daha Ã¶zenli bir yaklaÅÂ±m istedi |publisher=Samanyoluhaber.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> and said that the aim of the Northern Cyprus protests was to make the government step down.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyprusnewsreport.com/?q=node/3688 |title=Cypriot Press Headlines Jan. 21 |publisher=Cyprus News Report |date=2011-01-21 |accessdate=2011-03-11}}</ref> A second demonstration was held on 2 March 2011. Around 40,000 people turned out.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mansethaber.com/kktcde_olayli_miting-dunya-haber-726.html |title=KKTC'de olaylÄ± miting | KKTC'de olaylÄ± miting,1.Toplumsal VaroluÅ Mitingi,KKTC gazetesi Yeni DÃ¼zen'in haberi,Sendikal Platform tarafÄ±ndan dÃ¼zenlenen ve grev eylemleriyle desteklenen miting,KKTC DE tc KARÅITI MÄ°TÄ°NGLER,sERDAR dENKTAÅ,AKP,SÄ°YASÄ° PARTÄ°LERÄ°N PANKARTLARI,MÄ°TÄ°NG ALANI |publisher=Mansethaber.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northcyprusdaily.com/news/Politics/Around-40000-North-Cypriot-people-took-part-in-the-protest-rally-757435.asp |title=Around 40,000 North Cypriot people took part in the protest rally - North Cyprus |publisher=Northcyprusdaily.com |date= |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> About 3,000 protesters turned out for a smaller march on the [[Assembly of the Republic (Northern Cyprus)|parliament]] building on 7 April to demand the independence of Northern Cyprus from the interference of the Turkish government, a demonstration that turned violent when police attempted to interfere. The ''[[Cyprus Mail]]'' reported that police were badly outnumbered and largely overwhelmed by the crowd, which resisted efforts by police to take down banners and detain particularly vehement protesters. It also reported that at least one protester displayed the [[flag of Cyprus]] at the Turkish Embassy, shouting that the flag represented all of Cyprus, not just the [[Greek Cypriot]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyprus-mail.com/cyprus/turkish-cypriot-discontent-grows/20110408|agency=Cyprus Mail|date=8 April 2011|accessdate=4 May 2011|title=Turkish Cypriot discontent grows|first=Simon|last=Bahceli}}</ref>
====Portugal==== {{Expand section|date=July 2011}} {{main|2011 Portuguese protests}}
