===Asia=== ====India==== {{Main|2011 Indian anti-corruption movement}} {{Main|West Bengal state assembly election, 2011}}
====Iraq==== {{Main|2011 Kurdish protests in Iraq}}
Protests broke out in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]], an autonomous region of [[Iraq]], on 21 February. They continued until martial law was declared in late April and the [[Peshmerga]], supported by the regular [[Iraqi Army]], was deployed to quell the unrest.<ref>{{cite news|first=Namo|last=Abdulla|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/29/us-iraq-protests-kurdish-idUSTRE73S2MW20110429|title=Military presence halts protests in Iraq's Kurdistan|agency=Reuters|date=29 April 2011|accessdate=1 May 2011}}</ref>
====Iran==== {{Main|2011 Iranian protests}}
On 9 February, various Iranian opposition groups requested permission from the Ministry of Interior to protest under the supervision of the Iranian police. Permission was refused.<ref>{{cite news |title=Protests wash over Iran, Bahrain and Yemen, inspired by Arab world unrest |author= |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/protests-wash-over-iran-bahrain-and-yemen-inspired-by-arab-world-unrest-1.343352 |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> Despite this setback, along with crackdowns on activists and members of opposition parties, opposition leaders such as [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]] called for nationwide protest marches to begin on 14 February.<ref>{{cite web|author=english.aljazeera.net |title=Iran opposition planning protests|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011212162526150718.html |publisher=aljazeera |date=|accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iran's 'Day of Rage' |author= |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/day_of_rage_blog/2299873.html?page=1&x=1#relatedInfoContainer |newspaper=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref>
Rumours suggested that the protesters would include university students, lorry drivers, and gold merchants from across the country, who were protesting under the umbrella opposition known as the [[2009â2010 Iranian election protests|Green movement]], the emergence of which had been inspired by the recent events in Egypt and Tunisia. The [[Army of the Guardians of the Islamic Revolution|Revolutionary Guard]] promised to forcefully confront protesters,<ref>{{cite web|author=D. Parvaz|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011212162526150718.html|title=Iran opposition 'planning protests' - Middle East|publisher=Al Jazeera English|year=|accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> and opposition activists and aides to Mousavi and Karroubi were arrested in the days leading up to the demonstrations.
As they had in the 2009 protests, opposition protesters chanted '[[Allahu Akbar]]' and 'Death to the dictator' into the early morning hours. In addition to using slogans from 2009 praising Mousavi,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8lAsWb3Kdwo |title=Iran - 25 Bahman 14 Feb 2011 - ya hossein mir hossein p51) |author=onlymehdi |date=14 February 2011 |work= |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=14 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A6hLglv_Lgk |title=Tehran - Feb 14/Ø¨ÙÙ Ù- ØªÙØ±Ø§Ù - 12 Û²Ûµ) |author=IranFree88 |date=14 February 2011 |work= |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=14 March 2011}}</ref> protestors also chanted 'Mubarak, Ben Ali, now its time for Seyed Ali [Khamenei]'.
Estimates of the number of protesters ranged from 'thousands' to 'hundreds of thousands', depending on the source.<ref>^ "Hot Air In Iran Protest Numbers" . 2011-02-15.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/tehranbureau/2011/02/iran-live-blog-25-bahman-14-february.html|title=Tehran Bureau: Iran Live Blog: 25 Bahman|publisher=PBS|year=|accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref>
Reports from the demonstrations described clashes between protesters and security forces in [[Tehran]]. As part of the government strategy, security forces of approximately 10,000 personnel were deployed to prevent protesters from gathering at Azadi Square, where the marches that had originated in Enghelab, Azadi, and Vali-Asr streets were expected to converge. Police reportedly fired tear gas and used pepper spray and batons to disperse protesters.<ref>^ a b "US sends Twitter messages to Iranians" . Agence France-Presse. 14 February 2011. Retrieved February 14, 2011.</ref><ref>^ Ladane Nasseri (14 February 2011). "Iran Cheers Revolts as Ahmadinejad Foes See Parallel" . Bloomberg. Retrieved 14 February 2011.</ref> Protesters responded by setting fires in garbage bins.<ref>^ a b c Ali Akbar Dareini (14 February 2011). "Police disperse Iranian protesters with tear gas" . Forbes. Retrieved 14 February 2011.</ref>
Clashes were also reported in [[Isfahan]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Al Jazeera English|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121412571299951.html|title=Clashes reported in Iran protests|publisher=Al Jazeera English|year=|accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref>
According to Saudi ''[[Al Arabiya]]'',<ref name=alarabiya>http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/04/18/145845.html</ref> Lebanese Yalibnan,<ref name=yalibnan>http://www.yalibnan.com/2011/04/16/iranseveral-arabs-killed-during-day-of-rage-in-ahwaz/</ref> the Guardian,<ref name=guardian>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/apr/18/iranian-sunni-protesters-killed | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Iranian Sunni protesters killed in clashes with security forces | date=18 April 2011}}</ref> there were large scale protests, declared as "Day of Rage" by Ahvaz [[Arab]] minority,<ref name=yalibnan/><ref name=amnesty>http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/iran-arab-minority-protest-deaths-must-be-investigated-2011-04-19</ref> in the city of [[Ahvaz]] - capital of the Khuzestan province, and the nearby town of Hamidieh. The protests marked 6 years since the violent [[2005 Ahwazi unrest|2005 Ahvaz unrest]].<ref name=amnesty/> The protesters were "demanding more rights and humanitarian benefits", as well as independence.<ref name=alarabiya/> The Revolutionary Guard Corps used tear gas to disperse the demonstrations, while using live bullets in some neighborhoods.<ref name=yalibnan/> Al-Arabiya reported that when the protests began, the city was blockaded by Iranian security forces, who "broke up demonstrations by force" and that "15 people from Ahwaz have been killed and dozens have been wounded".<ref name=alarabiya/> The Guardian puts the casualty rate at 12 dead Arabic-speaking Sunnis, based on [[Shirin Ebadi]]'s letter to the UN.<ref name=guardian/>
====Israel==== {{main|2011 Israeli housing protests}} {{main|Timeline of the 2011 Israeli housing protests}} [[File:Israel Housing Protests Tel Aviv August 6 2011b.jpg|thumb|250px|Israeli protests, July 2011]] The 2011 Israeli housing protests ([[Hebrew]]: ××××ª ×××××¨ or ××××ª ×× ××"× or ××××ª ×××××××) are a series of ongoing street demonstrations taking place throughout [[Israel]] from 14 July 2011 onwards. The protests began as a result of a [[Facebook]] protest group that initially led hundreds of people to camp in tents in the center of [[Tel Aviv]] on [[Rothschild Boulevard]], an act which soon gained momentum, media attention and began a public discourse in Israel regarding the [[Israel's housing bubble|high cost of housing]] and living expenses. Soon afterwards, the protests spread to many other [[cities in Israel]] as thousands of Israeli protesters began camping in tents in the middle of central streets in major Israeli cities as a means of protest. The protesters object to increasing housing prices in Israel, and especially in the country's major cities, which they claim prevents [[affordable housing]].
It has been suggested in the media that the protests might have been inspired by the ongoing [[Arab Spring]],<ref>{{cite news|title=ISRAEL: Is the Arab Spring spreading to the Jewish state?|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/07/israel-protests-spread-demanding-social-justice.html|date=26 July 2011|accessdate=27 July 2011|work=Los Angeles Times|author=Batsheva Sobelman}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Has the Arab Spring arrived in Israel?|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatches/news/regions/middle-east/israel-and-palestine/has-the-arab-spring-arrived-israel|date=26 July 2011|accessdate=27 July 2011|publisher=globalpost|author=Peter Gelling}}</ref> The Israeli protests have generally been [[non-violent]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Arab Spring spirit inspires Israel tent cities|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2015675754_israelprotests21.html|date=20 July 2011|accessdate=27 July 2011|publisher=The Seattle Times|author=Ethan Bronner}}</ref> Still Israeli protesters took some of the Arab revolutions slogans like the word "Erhal" which means "Leave."
====Malaysia==== {{main|Bersih 2.0 rally}} On July 9, 2011, between 20,000 and 50,000 protesters took to the streets of the capital city of [[Kuala Lumpur]] to demand electoral reform. In the buildup to the protest, [[Royal Malaysian Police|Malaysian police]] arrested hundreds of activists from the non-governmental organisation [[Bersih]] which had organised the protests. Despite a heavy police cordon of Kuala Lumpur, tens of thousands of protesters managed to make their way into the capital city. The peaceful rally turned chaotic when police utilised tear gas and water cannons to disperse the crowds. There was evidence of [[police brutality]], with plainclothes policemen attacking unarmed protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZqCmcF7pZZI|title=Police Beating - Malaysiakini|date=2011-07-09 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> There was one death reported at the rally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/one-death-reported-at-rally|title=One death reported at rally - The Malaysian Insider|date=2011-07-09 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
====Maldives==== {{main|2011 Maldivian protests}} Early on Sunday, 1 May 2011, protests began in the Maldives with thousands of protesters demonstrated in [[Male, Maldives]] demanding that President [[Mohamed Nasheed]] step down. Police were sent in to break up the protests. Dozens were injured and many people were arrested during the demonstrations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/42842938 |title=Maldives police break up anti-gov't protest - World news - South and Central Asia - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date=2011-01-05 |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> Protests continued the following day too.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-13252906 | work=BBC News | title=Maldives rocked by protests against President Nasheed | date=1 May 2011}}</ref> Main causes for the protests were soaring food prices and rising unemployment. The main opposition party in the nation, the DRP (Maldivian People's Party) said that "currency devaluation has increased the price of essentials".<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/> Protests continued for days and are ongoing.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-13269801 | work=BBC News | title=Maldives hit by third night of anti-government protests | date=3 May 2011}}</ref><ref>http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asia/235288/fourth-night-of-protests-in-maldives</ref>
====Myanmar==== A protest campaign to "attempt to emulate the democratic revolution in Egypt that was sparked by a Facebook campaign" started in [[Myanmar]] on 13 February 2011, coordinating via a [[Facebook]] page titled "Just Do It Against Military Dictatorship".<ref name="irrawaddy_Burma_13Feb">{{cite news | first=Ba | last=Kaung | pages= | language =| title=Burmese Attempt Own 'Facebook Revolution' | date=2011-03-02 | publisher=[[The Irrawaddy]] | url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=20859 |accessdate=2011-03-03 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wyCy9hmm |archivedate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Anti-government material was distributed in several places around the country, including [[Mandalay]] and [[Taunggyi]]. More than 1000 activists support the campaign.<ref name="irrawaddy_Burma_13Feb" /> An intense series of anti-government street protests took place in [[2007 Burmese anti-government protests|September to November 2007]].
====North Korea==== The [[Republic of Korea Armed Forces|South Korean military]] dropped leaflets with information about the protests in Egypt and Libya into [[North Korea]], in an attempt to induce political change in its northern neighbor, with whom it has technically been [[Korean War|at war]] since the 1940s.<ref>{{cite news|title=South Korea leaflets tell North of Egypt, but change unlikely |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/25/us-korea-north-campaign-idUSTRE71O0SM20110225 |agency=Reuters |date=25 February 2010 |accessdate=27 February 2011}}</ref> North Korea threatened to take military action if South Korea continued to drop leaflets fomenting revolt, Korean Central News Agency reported.<ref>{{cite web|last=Yang|first=Jun|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-27/north-korea-warns-of-military-response-against-south-over-leaflet-drops.html|title=North Korea Warns of Military Response Against South Over Leaflet Air Drop|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|year=|accessdate=2011-02-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Post Store|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/26/AR2011022604127.html|title=North Korea threatens to attack South Korea, US|publisher=Washingtonpost.com|date=2011-02-16|accessdate=2011-02-27}}</ref> According to reports in the South Korean media, there have been small pockets of protests in North Korea.<ref name="straits_NKpockets">{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_638328.html |title=Isolated protests break out in North Korea |publisher=Straitstimes.com |date=2011-02-24 |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref>
====People's Republic of China==== {{main|2011 Chinese pro-democracy protests}} There were calls made via social networks such as [[Twitter]] to begin a "Jasmine Revolution" in China. [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese authorities]] arrested activists,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/20/chinese-officials-detain-activists-protests|title=China detains activists after online call for protests|author=Tania Branigan|publisher=The Guardian|location=London|date=20 February 2011}}</ref> increased the normal police presence, disabled some [[Mobile phone industry in China|cell phone]] [[text messaging]] services and [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|deleted Internet postings]] about protests planned for 14:00 on 20 February in [[Beijing]], [[Shanghai]] and 11 other cities.<ref name="China tries to stamp out">{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-02-20-china-jasmine-revolution_N.htm|title=China tries to stamp out 'Jasmine Revolution'|publisher=[[usatoday.com]]|date=20 Feb 2011|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/20/unrest-morocco-iran-algeria-yemen-china|title=Anger on the streets: unrest in Iran, Algeria, Yemen, Morocco and China|publisher=The Guardian | location=London|first1=Giles|last1=Tremlett|date=20 February 2011}}</ref> On the day of the protests, the police turned out en masse to all of the potential protest locations in various cities around the country.<ref name="NYChina">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/21/world/asia/21china.html|title=Chinese Security Officials Respond to Call for Protests|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Jacob, Andrew|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> Small crowds, including a large number of foreign journalists, gathered at the planned site in [[Beijing]] and [[Shanghai]] but did not chant slogans or hold signs.<ref name="china-telegraph">{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8336611/China-snuffs-out-democracy-protests.html|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph|first1=Peter|last1=Foster|first2=Malcolm|last2=Moore|title=China snuffs out democracy protests|date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12517909|work=BBC News|title=China police break up 'protests' after online appeal|date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iblKmk0zFyrloDdKUWP56cuOfD2Q?docId=CNG.7a0509e93accafbdfd4785aad6cc3018.5b1|title=China cracks down after calls for protests|first=Robert|last=Saiget|work=AFP|publisher=Google|date=February 20, 2011|accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/20/us-china-protests-idUSTRE71J0TV20110220|agency=Reuters|title=Chinese police snuff out planned Arab-inspired protests|date=2011-02-20}}</ref> [[CPC General Secretary]] and President [[Hu Jintao]] responded by calling top leaders into a "study session" to root out and tackle social issues before they "become threats to stability".<ref name="NYChina"/> In a speech at the [[Central Party School of the Communist Party of China|Central Party School]], Hu called out for tighter restrictions to the internet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703498804576156203874160350.html?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Call for Protests Unnerves China|author=Page, Jeremy|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
Chinese Premier [[Wen Jiabao]] promised to curb [[inflation]] and punish [[corruption in China|corruption]] in what was seen as an attempt to curb protests. He also promised to boost food supplies and to control surging property prices.<ref>{{cite web|author=1:33 PM ET|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-27/china-s-wen-vows-to-contain-food-home-prices-amid-jasmine-protest-calls.html|title=China's Wen Vows to Contain Food, Home Prices Amid `Jasmine' Protest Calls|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|year=|accessdate=2011-02-27}}</ref> A heavy police presence was also reported in planned protest cities of Beijing and Shanghai.<ref>{{cite web|author=4:07 PM ET|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-27/china-police-blanket-planned-jasmine-protest-sites-in-beijing-shanghai.html|title=Wen Pledges to Curb Graft, Income Inequality as Police Head Off Protests|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|year=|accessdate=2011-02-27}}</ref> He said that fighting inflation was an important economic priority in order to curb social unrest.<ref>{{cite web|author=5:51 PM ET |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-05/china-targets-8-growth-this-year-wen-pledges-to-decisively-curb-prices.html |title=China Targets 8% Growth This Year as Wen Vows to `Decisively' Curb Prices |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref>
During an interview given to [[Jeffrey Goldberg]] of [[The Atlantic]], [[Hillary Clinton]] responded to Goldberg's comment: "Chinese government seemed scared of the [[Arab Spring|Arab rising]]": "Well, they are. They're worried, and they are trying to stop history, which is a [[Snipe hunt|fool's errand]]. They cannot do it. But they're going to hold it off as long as possible." <ref>http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/05/hillary-clinton-chinese-system-is-doomed-leaders-on-a-fools-errand/238591/ Hillary Clinton: Chinese System Is Doomed, Leaders on a 'Fool's Errand' By Jeffrey Goldberg May 10, 2011</ref>
=====Tibetan government-in-exile===== In March 2011, the [[14th Dalai Lama]] Tenzin Gyatso announced that he would step down from his political office as the leader of the Tibetan government-in-exile, making way for the election of a prime minister. The move was read{{By whom|date=July 2011}} of splitting the political and religious authority of the Tibetan leadership-in-exile. He called the rule of spiritual leaders "outdated" and added: "I do not want to be like [[Mubarak]]."<ref>{{cite news |title=Dalai Lama: I do not want to be like Mubarak |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/9/7953/World/International/Dalai-Lama-I-do-not-want-to-be-like-Mubarak.aspx |accessdate= 20 June 2011}}</ref> An election took place on 20 March 2011 and the new prime minister of the Tibetan government-in-exile is [[Lobsang Sangay]].
====Turkey==== {{main|2011 Kurdish protests in Turkey}} In Turkey supporters of BDP, the main pro-Kurdish party, have demonstrated against the Turkish government before and after the general elections.
====Vietnam==== {{See also|Vietnamese democracy movement}} Rare protests in [[Vietnam]] and an alleged case of self-immolation <ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/20/vietnam-self-immolation-to-protest-corruption|title=Self immolation to protest corruption|accessdate=2011-03-02}}</ref> were reported in [[Ho Chi Minh City]] and [[Da Nang]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/asia-pacific/2011/02/201122611524710573.html|title=Protest fever reaches Vietnam - Asia-pacific|publisher=Al Jazeera English|year=|accessdate=2011-02-27}}</ref>
[[Nguyen Dan Que]], a prominent government critic, was arrested on 26 February 2011 because security services said he was caught "red-handed keeping and distributing documents" that called for the overthrow of the government in a Middle East-style uprising.<ref name="alj_VN">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/live-blog-libya-march-1 |title=Live Blog - Libya March 1 | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref>
===The Americas=== Starting with the [[2011 United States public employee protests|February]] protests in [[Wisconsin]] a number of Arab Spring inspired movements have waxed and waned in both Americas, some being violent, others not. On October 15, there were thousands of demonstrations throughout the two continents, some in countries such as [[Occupy Canada|Canada]], which had not suffered such unrest before.
====Bolivia==== {{main|Presidency of Evo Morales#2011}} On 10 February the President of [[Bolivia]], [[Evo Morales]], cancelled an appearance at a public event in [[Oruro, Bolivia|Oruro]] due to fears over riots after protesters angry about rising food prices and Morales' style of government reportedly planted explosives there. Morales was said to be "on guard" in the wake of the Tunisian and Egyptian uprisings according to [[United Press International]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2011/02/11/Morales-aborts-visit-amid-fears-of-food-riots/UPI-56061297458214/|title=Morales aborts visit amid fears of food riots|publisher=UPI.com|year=|accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> Protests against the president were also reported in several of the country's major cities.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Associated Press|url=http://www.heraldonline.com/2011/02/11/2827401/bolivian-president-rattled-by.html|title=Bolivian president rattled by protests|work=The Herald | location=Rock Hill, South Carolina|date=2011-02-11|accessdate=2011-02-13}}{{dead link|year=February 2011|date=February 2011}}</ref> On 29 September, thousands of people marched to protest [[Evo Morales|Morales]]' attacks on indigionus people over highway construction.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/sep/29/bolivians-march-against-evo-morales?newsfeed=true | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Bolivians march against Evo Morales over jungle highway crackdown | date=29 September 2011}}</ref> He later apologized.
==== Chile ==== {{main|2011 Chilean protests}}
==== Mexico ==== {{main|2011 Mexican protests}} Mass demonstrations have occurred against Mexican President [[Felipe CalderÃ³n]], calling for an end to the [[Mexican Drug War]], citing inspiration from the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://narcosphere.narconews.com/thefield/4372/and-what-history-looks-mexico |title=The Field: And This Is What History Looks Like in Mexico |publisher=Narcosphere.narconews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref>
==== United States ====
[[Image:2011 Wisconsin Budget Protests 1 JO.jpg|thumb|300px|Thousands gather outside of the Wisconsin Capitol building to protest Governor Walker's bill. The gathering is estimated at 70,000 to 100,000 people.<ref name="LAT_27th">{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-wisconsin-protests-20110227,0,3378088.story|author=Abby Sewell|title=Protesters out in force nationwide to oppose Wisconsin's anti-union bill|work=Los Angeles Times|date=February 27, 2011}}</ref>]] {{main|2011 Wisconsin protests|2011 United States public employee protests|Occupy Wall Street|"Occupy" protests}} A series of demonstrations took place in the United States, starting on 14 February 2011 and continuing {{as of|2011|03|12|lc=y}},<ref name="wis_100k_14March">{{cite news | first=Roger | last=Bybee | pages= | language =| title=In Madison, Nearly 100,000 Protest Gov. Walker's Corporatist Vision | date=2011-03-14 | publisher=[[In These Times]] | url=http://inthesetimes.com/article/7062/in_madison_nearly_100000_protest_gov._walkers_corporatist_vision |accessdate=2011-03-16 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xEkjLNKr |archivedate=2011-03-16 |deadurl=no }}</ref> involving tens of thousands of [[protestor]]s including [[Trade union|union]] members, students, and other citizens. The protests main aims relate to [[collective bargaining]] legislation and took place mainly around the [[Wisconsin State Capitol]], located in [[Madison, Wisconsin]],<ref name="usatoday_egypt_wisconsin">{{cite news | first=Catalina | last=Camia | pages= | language =| title=Rep. Paul Ryan compares Wisconsin protests to Cairo | date=2011-02-17 | work=[[USA Today]] | url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/onpolitics/post/2011/02/paul-ryan-wisconsin-protests-egypt/1 |accessdate=2011-02-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wb2wPvMS |archivedate=2011-02-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref> with smaller protests in the cities of [[Milwaukee]] and [[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay]], at various university campuses including the [[University of WisconsinâMadison]] and the [[University of WisconsinâMilwaukee]], and spread to another US state capital, [[Columbus, Ohio]].<ref name="bloom_USAspreadOhio">{{cite news | first=Mark | last=Niquette | pages= | language =| title=Public Worker Protests Spread From Wisconsin to Ohio | date=2011-02-18 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-17/public-employee-union-protests-spread-from-wisconsin-to-ohio.html |accessdate=2011-02-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wb13xKZL |archivedate=2011-02-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref> In September 17, 2011, protest sprawn around New York City in the financial district [[Wall Street]] called [[Occupy Wall Street]]. The protests reaction of recent government bailouts for financial institution and the growing wealth inequity in America. This moment would be called the [["Occupy" protests|"Occupy" moment]] springing up in cities across the United States.
The protests were considered to be inspired by the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]] by the chairman of the [[United States House Committee on the Budget]], [[Paul Ryan]] and the [[Late-2000s recession]].<ref name="usatoday_egypt_wisconsin" /> Linguist [[Noam Chomsky]] said that the Wisconsin protests and the Egyptian revolution "are closely intertwined", and that both consist of "struggles for [[labor rights]] and [[democracy]]".<ref name="wis_eg_chomsky">{{cite web| last =Chomsky| first =Noam| authorlink =Noam Chomsky| coauthors =| title =The Cairo-Madison Connection| work =| publisher =[[Z Communications]] | date =2011-03| url =http://www.zcommunications.org/the-cairo-madison-connection-by-noam-chomsky |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-03-16 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xEdLFgzB |archivedate=2011-03-16 |deadurl=no }}</ref> [[Mike Lux]], a political consultant, stated that some of the protestors in Wisconsin and Ohio carried Egyptian flags and that "the pictures we are seeing and the story playing out in Wisconsin is like Egypt in some really important ways. The new mass militancy ... is a mass movement spreading like wildfire, building in momentum day by day."<ref name="MikeLux_analysis">{{cite news | first=Mike | last=Lux | pages= | language =| title=Egypt, Wisconsin, and the Future of Our Democracy | date=2011-02-18 | publisher=Huffington Post | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mike-lux/egypt-wisconsin-and-the-f_b_825185.html |accessdate=2011-02-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wb3qn1tG |archivedate=2011-02-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
=== Oceania === ==== Fiji ====
The New Zealand branch of human rights group [[Amnesty International]] reported that soldiers in the archipelago state of [[Fiji]], under military rule since [[2006 Fijian coup d'Ã©tat|2006]], were increasingly resulting to beatings, abuse, and even torture to enforce order, allegedly detaining and abusing opposition members, unionists, and youth activists for planning a protest against the [[junta]] in late February. Amnesty CEO [[Patrick Holmes]] said he believed the more violent tactics are intended to thwart a Middle East-inspired uprising against the junta in Fiji.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/pacbeat/stories/201102/s3149389.htm|agency=Radio Australia|title=Amnesty accuses Fiji military of a series of beatings|date=25 February 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=59075|title=Amnesty reports Fiji military beatings of young people|agency=Radio New Zealand International|date=2 March 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=59111|agency=Radio New Zealand International|date=3 March 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011|title=Fiji beatings a sign of regime's fear of revolt, says academic}}</ref> A Fiji pro-democracy group based in [[Sydney]] called for an international response to the alleged crackdown, comparing the situation in Fiji to the situation in Libya.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=59119|agency=Radio New Zealand International|date=4 March 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011|title=Group calls for international response to Fiji military's abuses}}</ref> On 7 March, ''[[The Australian]]'' reported that a former government minister declared his intent to seek asylum in Australia, claiming Fiji soldiers had detained and tortured him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/fijian-former-minister-to-seek-asylum/story-fn59niix-1226016769392|agency=The Australian|title=Fijian former minister to seek asylum|first=Michael|last=McKenna|date=7 March 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref> The Fiji military has denied this, with a highly placed officer telling [[Radio Australia]] that soldiers only use "some minimal force" when making arrests and denying any knowledge of either planned protests or martial action in response on the part of the military or police.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/pacbeat/stories/201103/s3158583.htm|agency=Radio Australia|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011|title=Fiji military denies its soldiers have beaten people}}</ref> One expert on Fiji politics told [[Radio New Zealand]] that he believed unrest within the military was a greater threat to Commodore [[Frank Bainimarama]]'s rule than popular protests like those in Tunisia and Egypt, but said it was hard to know what the junta's thinking was.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=59182|agency=Radio New Zealand International|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011|title=Internal strife the main fear for Fiji regime - academic}}</ref> New Zealand Foreign Minister [[Murray McCully]] said his government was seeking more information on the alleged beatings, echoing concerns expressed by the Australian government.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=59188|agency=Radio New Zealand International|date=7 March 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011|title=NZ seeks more information on alleged military beatings in Fiji}}</ref> The [[Fiji Human Rights Commission]] said that while it hasn't received any recent complaints directly, it is monitoring the situation and trying to check up on published allegations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=59348|agency=Radio New Zealand International|date=14 March 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011|title=Fiji human rights watchdog says no complaints of abuse by military}}</ref>
==Censorship and preemptive actions== ===Ethiopia=== Internet writer Eskinder Nega was warned after he wrote about the events in Egypt.<ref name="Sub-Saharan Africa censors Mideast">{{cite web |url=http://www.cpj.org/blog/2011/02/sub-saharan-africa-counters-censorship-on-mideast.php |title=Sub-Saharan Africa censors Mideast |publisher=The Committee to Protect Journalists |date=18 February 2011}}</ref>
Following Ben Ali's flight from Tunisia, the [[Ethiopian government]] said there would be a cap on the prices of essential foods.<ref name="donmino"/>
===Equatorial Guinea=== The government of [[Teodoro Obiang]], who has ruled the Equatorial Guinea for 32 years, censored news about the protests.<ref name="Sub-Saharan Africa censors Mideast"/>
===Eritrea=== The state-owned news agency censors news about the events. Independent media has been banned since 2001.<ref name="Sub-Saharan Africa censors Mideast"/>
===Kazakhstan=== On January 31, [[Kazakhstan]]'s President [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]] decided to scrap a [[Kazakhstani presidential term referendum, 2011|referendum]] which would have handed him a third decade in power by skipping elections due in 2012 and 2017. Nazarbayev supported the Constitutional Council's ruling that such a referendum would be unconstitutional and called an [[Kazakhstani presidential election, 2011|early election]] to be held on 3 April 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/01/us-kazakhstan-referendum-usa-idUSTRE7101VI20110201 |title=U.S. praises Kazakh leader for skipping referendum |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-02-01 |accessdate=2011-02-14 |first=Dmitry |last=Solovyov}}</ref> He also planned to offer the citizens of Kazakhstan discounted shares in some key national companies as part of a series of "People's [[IPO]]s" saying that "This is an event of paramount importance to the state...The whole world is earning money on stock markets and citizens of Kazakhstan should also learn how to do this." However, some critics suggested this was "window dressing", saying Nazarbayev merely was trying to deflect claims that too much wealth was controlled by a "corrupt, ruling elite."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2011/03/01/kazakhstan-shares-for-votes/ |title=Kazakhstan: shares for votes | beyondbrics | News and views on emerging markets from the Financial Times â FT.com |publisher=Blogs.ft.com |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> News media in [[South Africa]] have warned of a possible "Egypt effect" in Russia and the [[Post-Soviet states|former Soviet Union]].<ref name="donmino">{{cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2011-02-11-egyptian-aftershock-felt-most-by-israel/ |title=Egyptian aftershock felt most by Israel |publisher=[[Mail & Guardian Online]] |date=2011-02-11 |publisher=Mg.co.za |accessdate=2011-02-13 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wb82X8iv |archivedate=2011-02-18 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
===Nigeria=== The [[media in Nigeria]] speculated that similar events could take place there as the [[Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta]] in the south or [[Boko Haram]] in the north could exploit the "distortions within the Nigerian system, and the anger of an aggrieved segment of the populace."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osundefender.org/?p=11806 |title=Egypt/Tunisia: It could happen here |publisher=[[Osun Defender]] |date= |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> In the first week of February Boko Haram also threatened the Nigerian government that it would carry out a "full scale war."<ref>{{cite web|author=Alex Thurston |url=http://thinkafricapress.com/article/resurgent-islamists-threaten-war-nigeria |title=Resurgent Islamists Threaten War in Nigeria | Nigeria News & Opinion |publisher=[[Think Africa Press]] |date=2011-02-07 |accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref>
===Turkmenistan=== At least one well-regarded political analyst (published by ''[[Foreign Policy (magazine)|Foreign Policy]]'' and [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]) said that conditions in the Central Asian republic of [[Turkmenistan]] were similar enough to those in countries currently experiencing protests and revolts that the autocratic government of President [[Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov]] appears worried by the precedent of revolutions in North Africa and major political concessions in several [[Western Asia]]n states. Berdimuhamedov's regime has censored all news of the protests and governmental changes. There have also been some credible reports of Turkmenistani authorities attempting to keep tabs on all citizens both inside and outside the country, with Turkmenistanis whom the government judges to have spent too much time abroad allegedly warned they could be barred either from returning to their home country, or from leaving again once they do return.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://oilandglory.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/04/21/the_arab_spring_the_turkmen_case|agency=Foreign Policy|date=21 April 2011|accessdate=26 April 2011|first=Muhammad|last=Tahir|title=The Arab Spring: The Turkmen case}}</ref>
===Uzbekistan=== The [[Uzbekistan]]i government embraced a set of parliamentary reforms in late March that will grant the [[Legislative Chamber of Uzbekistan|Legislative Chamber]] of the [[Supreme Assembly of Uzbekistan|Supreme Assembly]], a democratically elected body, a stronger ability to check the power of the [[Prime Minister of Uzbekistan|prime minister]] by allowing it to call a [[motion of no confidence]], as well as empowering both houses of the Supreme Assembly to "demand information" from the executive branch, according to one Uzbekistani senator involved with the reform initiative. At least one prominent political analyst at an Interior Ministry-affiliated university in [[Tashkent]] said the reforms were inspired by recent revolutionary events in the Middle East and [[2010 Kyrgyzstani uprising|Kyrgyzstan]], asserting that democratization and government accountability and not violence are the means to forestalling popular upheaval.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://centralasiaonline.com/cocoon/caii/xhtml/en_GB/features/caii/features/main/2011/04/14/feature-01|agency=Central Asia Online|title=Uzbekistan strengthens parliament|date=14 April 2011|accessdate=21 April 2011|first=Shakar|last=Saadi}}</ref>
==Political fallout== ===France=== On February 28, 2011 French Foreign Minister [[Michele Alliot-Marie]] resigned after a month of pressure following allegations she offered French military assistance to ousted President [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] and that she vacationed in Tunisia during the unrest.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2011/feb/28/world/la-fg-france-foreign-20110228 "French minister quits over ties to ousted Tunisian regime"], Kim Willsher. Los Angeles Times. February 28, 2011. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref>
===Israel=== The Israeli intelligence agency, [[Mossad]], came under fire having previously assessed the Egyptian government as stable. As the protests in Egypt began, IDF Intelligence Chief [[Aviv Kochavi]] stated the Egyptian government was not in danger of collapsing.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4021489,00.html "Intelligence failure? Mubarak Couldn't Predict Uprising Either"], YNET News. January 31, 2011. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref> As a result, the Israeli government ordered a probe into the intelligence failures.<ref>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/162911.html "Israel to probe intelligence failure"], Press TV. January 31, 2011. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref>
===United Kingdom=== The [[London School of Economics]]' Howard Davies resigned over the institution's monetary support from Libya.<ref>[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/04/AR2011030406679.html "London School of Economics head resigns over school's Libyan ties"], March 5, 2011. Washington Post. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref><ref name="NZ_Herald_10710217">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/libya/news/article.cfm?l_id=467&objectid=10710217 |title=Gaddafi son holds key to oil money |author=Doward, Jamie |date=5 March 2011 |newspaper=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=4 October 2011}}</ref>
===United States=== President [[Barack Obama]], Defense Secretary [[Robert Gates]], CIA Director [[Leon Panetta]], Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]], and other high ranking officials and government agencies were caught by surprise over the uprisings, accused of presiding over a massive intelligence failure and being caught "flat footed."<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/11/cias-mideast-surprise-history-of-failures_n_822183.html#s239132&title=Iranian_Revolution_1979 "CIA's Mideast Surprise Recalls History of Intelligence Failures"], Marcus Baram. Huffington Post. February 11, 2011. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.npr.org/2011/02/22/133956664/weekly-standard-another-intelligence-failure "Weekly Standard: Another Intelligence Failure"], Abe Shulsky. Gary Schmitt. NPR. February 22, 2011. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.canadafreepress.com/index.php/article/32792 "Obama caught flat-footed on Egyptian uprising"], Jim Kouri. Canada Free Press. February 1, 2011. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref> Panetta, Deputy Secretary of State [[Jim Steinberg]],<ref>[http://thecable.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/02/10/panetta_and_steinberg_testify_on_egypt_as_mubarak_rumors_swirl "Panetta and Steinberg testify on Egypt as Mubarak rumors swirl"], Josh Rogin. Foreign Policy. February 10, 2011. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref> Director of Intelligence [[James Clapper]],<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12422018 "US intelligence chief James Clapper defends Egypt intel"], February 10, 2011. BBC. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref> and FBI Director [[Robert Mueller]] appeared before the 112th Congress's first [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|House Permanent Select Committee of Intelligence]] hearing to testify about Egypt and related failures.<ref>[http://www.nypost.com/p/news/opinion/editorials/leadership_test_kcKhrxfRcj1PIwrQS3DPbO "Leadership Test"], New York Post. February 12, 2011. Accessed March 9, 2011</ref>
